text: Writing is the only way to distance oneself from the century in which it was one's lot to be born.

Concerning himself intensely with his neighbor's condition allows the Christian to dissimulate to himself his doubts about the divinity of Christ and the existence of God.
Charity can be the most subtle form of apostasy.
The particular creature we love is never God's rival. What ends in apostasy is the worship of man, the cult of humanity.
Envy tends to be the true force behind moral indignation.
What is important is not that man believe in the existence of God; what is important is that God exist.
The Gospels and the Communist Manifesto are on the wane; the world's future lies in the power of Coca-Cola and pornography.

In their childish and vain attempt to attract the people, the modern clergy give socialist programs the function of being schemes for putting the Beatitudes into effect.
The trick behind it consists in reducing to a collective structure external to the individual an ethical behavior that, unless it is individual and internal, is nothing.
The modern clergy preach, in other words, that there is a social reform capable of wiping out the consequences of sin.
From which one can deduce the pointlessness of redemption through Christ.
The voter does not even vote for what he wants; he only votes for what he thinks he wants.
It is not just that human trash accumulates in cities - it is that cities turn what accumulates in them into trash.

As they cannot be defined univocally, nor irrefutably demonstrated, so-called 'human rights' serve as a pretext for the individual who rebels against a positive law.
The individual has no more rights than the benefit that can be inferred from another's duty.
Nobody in politics can foresee the consequences either of what he destroys, or of what he constructs.

The contemporary Church prefers to practice an electoral Catholicism.
It prefers the enthusiasm of great crowds to individual conversions.
Where Christianity disappears, greed, envy, and lust invent a thousand ideologies to justify themselves.
The modern metropolis is not a city; it is a disease.
Society until yesterday had notables; today it only has celebrities.
In the modern state there now exist only two parties: citizens and bureaucracy.
Fashion, even more than technology, is the cause of the modern world's uniformity.
The progressive Christian's error lies in believing that Christianity's perennial polemic against the rich is an implicit defense of socialist programs.
History is indeed the history of freedom - not of an essence 'Freedom,' but of free human acts and their unforeseeable consequences.
Ever since Wundt, one of the classic places of 'disguised unemployment' is the experimental psychology laboratory.
The so highly acclaimed 'dominion of man over nature' turned out to be merely an enormous capability to kill.
No one is more insufferable than a man who does not suspect, once in a while, that he might not be right.
Superficial, like the sociological explanation of any behavior.

If one does not believe in God, the only honest alternative is vulgar utilitarianism.
The rest is rhetoric.
A noble society is one where obeying and exercising authority are ethical behaviors, and not mere practical necessities.
That the abandonment of the 'what for' in the sciences has been productive is indisputable, but it is an admission of defeat.
Unlimited gullibility is required to be able to believe that any social condition can be improved in any other way than slowly, gradually, and involuntarily.
Nothing upsets the unbeliever as much as defenses of Christianity based on intellectual skepticism and internal experience.
The modern world resulted from the confluence of three independent causal series: the demographic expansion, democratic propaganda, the industrial revolution.
One must beware of those who are said 'to have much merit.' They always have some past to avenge.
A bureaucracy ultimately always ends up costing the people more than an upper class.
Compared to the sophisticated structure of every historical fact, Marxism's generalizations possess a touching naivetÃ©.

The modern clergy believe they can bring man closer to Christ by insisting on Christ's humanity.
Thus forgetting that we do not trust in Christ because He is man, but because He is God.

Those who insist on being up to date with today's fashion are less irritating than those who try too hard when they do not feel that they are up to date with tomorrow's fashion.
The bourgeoisie is aesthetically more tolerable than the avant-garde.

Modern man calls walking more quickly in the same direction down the same road 'change.'
The world, in the last three hundred years, has not changed except in that sense.
The simple suggestion of a true change scandalizes and terrifies modern man.

Historical events stop being interesting the more accustomed their participants become to judging everything in purely secular categories.
Without the intervention of gods everything becomes boring.
If we are ignorant of an epoch's art, its history is a colorless narrative.
The people that awakes, first shouts, then gets drunk, pillages, [and] murders, and later goes back to sleep.
Why not imagine the possibility, after several centuries of Soviet hegemony, of the conversion of a new Constantine?
Where the law is not customary law, it is easily turned into a mere political weapon.
The problem of increasing inflation could be solved, if the modern mentality did not put up insurmountable resistance against any attempt to restrain human greed.

The reactionary's ideal is not a paradisiacal society. It is a society similar to the society that existed in the peaceful intervals of the old European society, of Alteuropa, before the demographic, industrial, and democratic catastrophe.
In modern society, capitalism is the only barrier to the spontaneous totalitarianism of the industrial system.
It is not primitive cults that discredit religion, but American sects.
'Nature' was a pre-Romantic discovery which Romanticism propagated, and which technology is killing in our days.

There exist two interpretations of the popular vote, one democratic, the other liberal.
According to the democratic interpretation what the majority resolves upon is true; according to the liberal interpretation the majority merely chooses one option.
A dogmatic and absolutist interpretation, the one; a skeptical and discreet interpretation, the other.
The secret longing of every civilized society is not to abolish inequality, but to educate it.
Except in a few countries, trying to 'promote culture' while recommending the reading of 'national authors' is a contradictory endeavor.
No thesis is expounded with clarity except when it manages to be expounded by an intelligent man who does not share it.
Everything in the world ultimately rests on its own final “just because.”
Baroque, preciosity, modernism, are noble failings, but failings in the end.
An individual is defined less by his contradictions than by the way he comes to terms with them.
The modern clergy, in order to save the institution, try to rid themselves of the message.
The so-called prejudices of the upper classes tend to consist of accumulated experiences.
There are moments when the worst failing, the worst offense, the worst sin, seems to be bad manners.
The Church used to educate; the pedagogy of the modern world only instructs.
After having been, in the last century, the instrument of political radicalism, universal suffrage is becoming, as Tocqueville foresaw, a conservative mechanism.
Religion is socially effective not when it adopts socio-political solutions, but when it succeeds in having society be spontaneously influenced by purely religious attitudes.
We do not know anything perfectly except what we do not feel capable of teaching.
“To have faith in man” does not reach the level of blasphemy; it is just one more bit of stupidity.
Envy is the key to more stories than sex.
The left claims that the guilty party in a conflict is not the one who covets another’s goods but the one who defends his own.
Demographic pressure makes people brutish.
It is not in the hands of popular majorities where power is most easily perverted; it is in the hands of the semi-educated.
The majority of properly modern customs would be crimes in an authentically civilized society.
The Christian knows with certainty what his personal behavior should be, but he can never state for certain that he is not making a mistake by adopting this or that social reform.
The fool, seeing that customs change, says that morality varies.
In a healthy society, the state is the organ of the ruling class; in a hunchbacked society, the state is the instrument of a bureaucratic class.
Unjust inequality is not remedied by equality, but by just inequality.
Why deceive ourselves? Science has not answered a single important question.
The people is sometimes right when it is frightened; but is always wrong when it becomes enthusiastic.
The golden rule of politics is to make only minimal changes and to make them as slowly as possible.
Faith is part intuition and part wager.
The fragments of the past that survive embarrass the modern landscape in which they stand out.
The peddlers of cultural objects would not be annoying if they did not sell them with the rhetoric of an apostle.
The heresy that threatens the Church, in our time, is “worldliness.”
The industrialization of agriculture is stopping up the source of decency in the world.
Boring, like an illustrious foreign visitor.
The true Christian should not resign himself to the inevitable: he should trust in the impertinence of a repeated prayer.
Nothing is more irritating than the certainty with which a man who has had success in one thing gives his opinion on everything.
The social sciences abound in problems that are unintelligible by their very nature to both the American professor and the Marxist intellectual.
In addition to civilized societies and semi-civilized societies, there are pseudo-civilized societies.
An education without the humanities prepares one only for servile occupations.
Evening dress is the first step toward civilization.
Modern man lost his soul and is no longer anything but the sum total of his behaviors.
The people today does not feel free except when it feels authorized to respect nothing.
Perfect prose is prose which the ingenuous reader does not notice is well written.
Only the years teach us to deal with our ignorance tactfully.
Monarchs, in almost every dynasty, have been so mediocre that they look like presidents.
Civilization does not conquer definitively: it only celebrates sporadic victories.
Words are born among the people, flourish among writers, and die in the mouth of the middle class.

None of the high points of history has been planned.
The reformer can only be credited with errors.
Educating the individual consists in teaching him to distrust the ideas that occur to him.
It is fine to demand that the imbecile respect arts, letters, philosophy, the sciences, but let him respect them in silence.
Whereas contemporaries read only the optimist with enthusiasm, posterity rereads the pessimist with admiration.
Man’s full depravity does not become clear except in great urban agglomerations.
The principle of inertia and the notion of natural selection eliminated the necessity of attributing meaning to facts, but they did not demonstrate that meaning does not exist.
I have seen philosophy gradually fade away between my skepticism and my faith.
“Escapism” is the imbecile’s favorite accusation to make.
The gesture, rather than the word, is the true transmitter of traditions.
The sinister uniformity that threatens us will not be imposed by a doctrine, but by a uniform economic and social conditioning.
The Christian does not pretend that the problems posed by religion have been solved; instead, he transcends them.
Puritanism is the attitude that befits the decent man in the world today.
Public political discussion is not intellectually adult in any country.
It fell to the modern era to have the privilege of corrupting the humble.
In culture which is bought there are many false notes; the only culture that never goes out of tune is that which is inherited.
There is no sociological generalization that does not appear inadequate to the man to whom it applies.
What is difficult about a difficult philosopher is more often his language than his philosophy.

Neither improvisation by itself, nor meditation by itself, achieves anything important.
In reality, the only thing of value is the spontaneous fruit of forgotten meditations.
The victims of the most serious individual and social catastrophes are often not even aware: individuals become brutish, societies become degraded, unawares.
The improvised idea shines and then goes out.
There are arguments of increasing validity, but, in short, no argument in any field spares us the final leap.
The will is granted to man so that he can refuse to do certain things.
The greater part of an age’s political ideas depends on the state of military technology.
Our meditation should not consist of a theme proposed to our intelligence, but of an intellectual murmur accompanying our life.

When we suspect the extent of the innate, we realize that pedagogy is the technique of what is secondary.
We only learn what we were born to know.
In philosophy a single naïve question is sometimes enough to make an entire system come tumbling down.
They call crowning mediocre men “promoting culture.”
The results of modern “liberation” make us remember with nostalgia the abolished “bourgeois hypocrisies.”
Shows which are called technically “for adults” are not for adult minds.

The glory of the truly great writers is a glory artificially imposed on the public, an academic and subsidized glory.
Authentic, popular, spontaneous glory crowns none but mediocre men.
When it comes to knowledge of man, there is no Christian (provided he is not a progressive Christian) whom anybody has anything to teach.
Modern man believes he lives amidst a pluralism of opinions, when what prevails today is a stifling unanimity.

The immigration of the peasant into the cities was less disastrous than that of the notable from the people.
Rural society, on the one hand, lost the structure of prestige that used to discipline it, and the notable, on the other, was transformed into an anonymous particle of the amorphous human mass.
Even when patriotic historians become angry, the history of many countries is completely lacking in interest.
Man tries so hard to demonstrate in order to avoid the risk that he ultimately cannot avoid assuming.
History clearly demonstrates that governing is a task that exceeds man’s ability.
The classical humanities educate because they ignore the basic postulates of the modern mind.
Someone who did not learn Latin and Greek goes through life convinced, even though he may deny it, that he is only semi-cultured.
So that one does not live depressed among so many foolish opinions, it behooves one to remember at every moment that things obviously are what they are, no matter what the world’s opinion is.
Many are the things about which one must learn to smile without disrespect.
Everything that can be reduced to a system ends up in the hands of fools.
The limits of science are revealed with greater clarity by the waxing light of its triumphs.
The majority of new customs are old behaviors that western civilization had shamefacedly confined to its lower-class neighborhoods.
The police force is the only social structure in the classless society.
The majority of the tasks that this century’s typical ruler believes he is obliged to assume are nothing more than abuses of power.
God does not die, but unfortunately for man the subordinate gods like modesty, honor, dignity, decency, have perished.
Political regimes become tolerable when they begin to hold their own principles in contempt.
The nature of the work of art can depend on social conditions, but its aesthetic quality depends on nothing.
In modern art there were numerous trends that exhausted the aesthetic consciousness’s capacity for indignation.
Nothing is more common than to despise many persons who should actually arouse our envy.
For the fool, obsolete opinion and erroneous opinion are synonymous expressions.
The essential mechanism of history is the simple replacement of some individualities by others.
The economic cause produces “something,” but only the historical juncture decides “what.”
The historian who speaks of cause, and not of causes, should be fired immediately.
The Church’s function is not to adapt Christianity to the world, nor even to adapt the world to Christianity; her function is to maintain a counterworld in the world.
The ignoramus believes that the expression “aristocratic manners” signified insolent behavior; whoever investigates discovers that the expression signified courtesy, refinement, dignity.

“Meaning,” “significance,” “importance,” are terms which do not merely designate transitive relations.
There are things with meaning, significance, importance, in themselves.
Modern society works feverishly to put vulgarity within everyone’s reach.
What concerns the Christ of the Gospels is not the economic situation of the poor man, but the moral condition of the rich man.
In the modern world the number of theories is increasing that are not worth the trouble to refute except with a shrug of the shoulders.

Liberty’s remaining partisans in our time tend to forget that a certain old and trivial bourgeois thesis is the proof itself: the condition sine qua non of liberty, for the proletariat as well as for the owners, is the existence of private property.
Direct defense of liberty for the ones; indirect defense of liberty for the others.
Human warmth in a society diminishes by the same measure that its legislation is perfected.
Rites preserve, sermons undermine faith.
In unremarkable texts we soon trip on phrases that penetrate into us, as if a sword has been thrust into us up to the hilt.
Something is modern if it is the product of an initial act of pride; something is modern if it seems to allow us to escape the human condition.
More so than the immorality of the contemporary world, it is its growing ugliness that moves one to dream of a cloister.

If determinism is real, if only that can happen which must happen, error does not exist.
Error supposes that something happened that should not have.
We who want to admit nothing but what has value, will always seem naïve to those who recognize nothing but what is in force.
By denouncing corruption, press publicity spreads it.
We are fully convinced only by the idea that does not need arguments to convince us.
Faith is not an explanation, but rather confidence that the explication ultimately exists.
What is difficult about every moral or social problem is based on the fact that its appropriate solution is not a question of all or nothing, but of more or less.
It is from a mistaken accentuation that the majority of the errors in our interpretation of the world proceed.
The wealth of a merchant, of an industrialist, of a financier, is aesthetically inferior to wealth in land and flocks.
“Social utility” is a criterion that slightly degrades what it seeks to justify.
The onslaught of words unleashed by an unlimited freedom of expression ends up reducing errors and truths to an equal insignificance.
Tolerating even stupid ideas can be a social virtue; but it is a virtue that sooner or later receives its punishment.
Unlimited tolerance is nothing more than a hypocritical way of resigning.
Once the intoxication of youth is over, only commonplaces appear to us to deserve careful examination.
Faith is not a conviction we possess, but a conviction that possesses us.
The nature of the effect, in history, depends on the nature of the individual on which the cause acts.
The diversity of history is the effect of always equal causes acting on always diverse individualities.
The line between intelligence and stupidity is a shifting line.
The pleasure of guessing the ingenious meaning of a metaphor tries to replace, in modern “poetry,” the mysterious joy of song.

In the intelligent man faith is the only remedy for anguish.
The fool is cured by “reason,” “progress,” alcohol, work.
Political activity ceases to tempt the intelligent writer, when he finally understands that there is no intelligent text that will succeed in ousting even a small-town mayor.
Envy differs from the other vices by the ease with which it disguises itself as a virtue.
A civilized society requires that in it, as in the old Christian society, equality and inequality be in permanent dialogue.
The embourgeoisement of Communist societies is, ironically, modern man’s last hope.
Even though they are full of threats, I fail to see anything in the Gospels but promises.
A “revolutionary” today means an individual for whom modern vulgarity is not triumphing quickly enough.
Our spontaneous aversions are often more lucid than our reasoned convictions.
A healthily constituted state is one where innumerable obstacles restrict and impede the freedom of the legislator.
Marxism and psychoanalysis have been the two traps of the modern intelligence.
To philosophize is to guess, without ever being able to know whether we are right.
There are two equally erroneous attitudes toward Marxism: disdaining what it teaches, believing what it promises.
After experiencing what an age practically without religion consists of, Christianity is learning to write the history of paganism with respect and sympathy.
I am not so dumb as to deny the indisputable successes of modern art; but when I look at modern art in itself, just as when I look at Egyptian or Chinese art, I feel like I am looking at exotic art.
I would not live for even a fraction of second if I stopped feeling the protection of God’s existence.
The most persuasive reason to renounce daring progressive opinions is the inevitability with which sooner or later the fool finally adopts them.
They speak emphatically of “transforming the world,” when the most to which they can aspire is to certain secondary remodelings of society.
The social sciences are not, properly speaking, inexact sciences, but sciences of the inexact.
The ultimate reality is not that of the object constructed by reason, but that of the voice answered by sensibility.
My convictions are the same as those of an old woman praying in the corner of a church.
Liberty is not the fruit of order alone; it is the fruit of mutual concessions between order and disorder.
In spiritually arid centuries, the only man to realize that the century is dying from thirst is the man who still harnesses an underground spring.
Formulating the problems of today in a traditional vocabulary strips away their false pretenses.
The only pellucid dialogue is one between two recluses.

All that is most excellent in history is a result of singularly unstable equilibriums.
Nothing endures for sure, but the mediocre lasts longer.
It is above all against what the crowd proclaims to be “natural” that the noble soul rebels.
Doubts do not fade one by one: they disappear in a flash of light.
Even if he were to succeed in making his most audacious utopias a reality, man would continue to yearn for otherworldly destinies.
The lower truths tend to eclipse the highest truths.
The state has not behaved with discretion and restraint except when it has been watched by rich bourgeoisies.
It is upon the antinomies of reason, upon the scandals of the spirit, upon the ruptures in the universe, that I base my hope and my faith.
To substitute a democratic government for another, non-democratic government comes down to substituting the beneficiaries of the pillaging.

Man’s freedom does not free him from necessity.
But twists it into unforeseeable consequences.
Only religion can be popular without being vulgar.
Man no longer knows how to invent anything that does not serve to kill better or to make the world a little more vulgar.
An intelligent touch can make the austerity imposed by poverty culminate in the perfection of taste.
Cultural rhetoric today replaces patriotic rhetoric, in the effusive expectorations of fools.

Rather than from the disturbing spectacle of injustice triumphing, it is from the contrast between the earthly fragility of the beautiful and its immortal essence that the hope of another life is born.
The politician never says what he believes to be true, but rather what he considers to be effective.
The spectacle of humanity does not acquire a certain dignity except thanks to the distortion it undergoes in history due to time.
“Historical necessity” is usually just a name for human stupidity.

Nobody is ignorant of the fact that historical events are made up of four factors: necessity, coincidence, spontaneity, freedom.
Nevertheless, it is rare to find a historiographical school that does not seek to reduce them to a single factor.
Only he who suggests more than what he expresses can be reread.
The notion of determinism has exercised a corrupting and terrorizing influence on the task of philosophy.
There is no coincidence in history that does not submit to the coincidence of the circumstances.
Man never calculates the price of any comfort he gains.
Determining what is the cause and what is the effect tends to be an insoluble problem in history.
Intellectual boorishness is the defect that we least know how to avoid in this century.
Man does not become educated through the knowledge of things but through the knowledge of man.
There is no social science so exact that the historian does not need to correct and adapt it to be able to use it.
In history, understanding the individual and understanding the general condition each other reciprocally.
Grand theories of history become useful when they give up trying to explain everything.
One can only speak of the sovereignty of the law where the legislator’s function is reduced to consulting the consensus of custom in the light of ethics.
A man does not become stultified by his prejudices unless he believes they are conclusions.

Neither a declaration of human rights, nor the proclamation of a constitution, nor an appeal to natural law, protects against the arbitrary power of the state.
The only barrier to despotism is customary law.
Inequality and equality are theses that should be defended alternatively, in opposition to the dominant social climate.
Everything in history begins before where we think it begins, and ends after where we think it ends.
Even the most austere rulers end up attending the circus in order to please the crowd.
Not all defeated men are decent, but all decent men end up being defeated.
The modern desire to be original makes the mediocre artist believe that simply being different is the secret to being original.
Man is important only if it is true that a God has died for him.

The day is made up of its moments of silence.
The rest is lost time.
Sensibility is a compass less susceptible of going crazy or misleading than is “reason.”
Falsifying the past is how the left has sought to elaborate the future.
Those who defend revolutions cite speeches; those who accuse them cite facts.

Between the causes of a revolution and its realization in actions ideologies insert themselves which end up determining the course and even the nature of events.
“Ideas” do not “cause” revolutions, but channel them.
When a revolution breaks out, the appetites are placed at the service of ideals; when the revolution triumphs, ideals are placed at the service of the appetites.

When those elected in a popular election do not belong to the lowest intellectual, moral, social strata of the nation, we can be sure that clandestine anti-democratic mechanisms have interfered with the normal outcome of the vote.
In religious matters the triviality of the objections tends to be more obvious than the fragility of the proofs.
The reactionary’s objection is not discussed; it is disdained.
Modern man defends nothing energetically except his right to debauchery.
When he repudiates rites, man reduces himself to an animal that copulates and eats.
Certain ideas are only clear when formulated, but others are only clear when alluded to.
The spectacle of a failure is perhaps less melancholy than the spectacle of a triumph.
People without imagination chill our soul.
To speak about God is presumptuous; not to speak of God is idiotic.
Our life is an anecdote that hides our true personality.
The perfect transparency of a text is, with nothing more, a sufficient delight.
The realism of photography is false: it omits in its representation of the object its past, its transcendence, its future.
Nothing is more disquieting to an intelligent unbeliever more than an intelligent Catholic.
Humanity is what is elaborated in man’s animality by reserve and modesty.
Those who replace the “letter” of Christianity with its “spirit” generally turn it into a load of socio-economic nonsense.
Knowing solves only subordinate problems, but learning protects against tedium.
The vice which afflicts the right is cynicism, and that which afflicts the left is deceit.
Man does not have the same density in every age.
Among those elected by popular suffrage only the imbeciles are respectable, because the intelligent man had to lie in order to be elected.
To know an historical episode well consists in not observing it through democratic prejudices.
Where Communism triumphs, silence falls with the sound of a trap closing shut.
The sociologist never knows, when manipulating his statistics, where the relative figure matters and where the absolute figure matters.
Where equality allows freedom to enter, inequality slips in.
Stupidity appropriates what science invents with diabolical facility.
The philosopher’s intuitions sometimes dazzle us; his ratiocinations make us bristle with objections.
The most ironic thing about history is that foreseeing is so difficult and having foreseen so obvious.
Individualism is the cradle of vulgarity.
The authentic vocation becomes indifferent to its failure or to its success.
Since philosophy is a dialogue, there is no reason to suppose that the last one to give his opinion is the one who is right.
Philosophies begin in philosophy and end in rhetoric.
Every man lives his life like a pent-up animal.
The commonplaces of the Western tradition are the guidelines that do not deceive in the social sciences.
Man is an animal that can be educated, provided he does not fall into the hands of progressive pedagogues.
A simple fit of impatience often soon bridges the distance between utopia and murder.
The modern clergy declare that Christianity seeks to solve earthly problems—thereby confusing it with utopia.
No writer has ever been born who did not write too much.
Whoever insists on refuting idiotic arguments ends up doing so with stupid reasons.
“Sexual liberation” allows modern man to pretend to be ignorant of the multiple taboos of another kind that govern him.
He who does not search for God at the bottom of his soul finds there nothing but muck.
To do what we ought to do is the content of the Tradition.
We can only hope for a reform of society to come from the contradictions between human follies.
Words are the true adventures of the authentic writer.
Souls that Christianity does not prune never mature.
The philosopher becomes unbalanced easily; only the moralist tends not to lose his reason.
We are saved from daily tedium only by the impalpable, the invisible, the ineffable.
One usually does not reach conclusions except by ignoring objections.
Mechanization is stultifying because it makes man believe that he lives in an intelligible universe.
Nothing arouses more mutual disdain than a difference in pastimes.
Asking the state to do what only society should do is the error of the left.
Sincerity, unless it is in a sacramental confession, is a factor leading to demoralization.
Each day modern man knows the world more and man less.
The imbecile is betrayed less by what he says than by his diction.
Only to defend our secondary convictions do we possess abundant arguments.
An “explanation” consists in the end in assimilating a strange mystery to a familiar mystery.
I have no pretensions to originality: the commonplace, if it is old, will do for me.
A class-conscious proletariat, in Marxist vocabulary, means a people that has converted to bourgeois ideals.

The basic problems of an age have never been the theme of its great literary works.
Only ephemeral literature is an “expression of society.”
To believe that an obvious truth, clearly expressed, should be convincing, is no more than a naïve prejudice.
The modern mentality is the child of human pride puffed up by commercial advertising.
Let us be careful not to call accepting what degrades us without any resistance “accepting life.”
Love uses the vocabulary of sex to write a text unintelligible to sex alone.
In the social sciences, one should only generalize in order to individualize better.
Life is a daily struggle against one’s own stupidity.
Interesting autobiographies would be plentiful if writing the truth were not an aesthetic problem.
Nothing is so important that it does not matter how it is written.
They started out calling liberal institutions democratic, and they ended up calling democratic despotisms liberal.
Economic claims, hostility between social classes, religious differences, tend to be mere pretexts for an instinctive appetite for conflict.
The modern machine becomes more complex every day, and every day modern man becomes more elemental.
There are certain types of ignorance that enrich the mind and certain types of knowledge that impoverish it.
Without literary talent the historian inevitably falsifies history.
History exhibits too many useless corpses for any finality to be attributed to it.
To give an aged truth its freshness back, it is enough to oppose it to a new error.
The temptation for the churchman is to carry the waters of religion in the sieve of theology.

When one is confronted by diverse “cultures,” there are two symmetrically erroneous attitudes: to admit only one cultural standard, and to grant all standards the same rank.
Neither the overweening imperialism of the European historian of yesterday, nor the shameful relativism of the European historian of today.
There is some collusion between skepticism and faith: both undermine human presumptuousness.
Good taste that has been learned ends up being of worse taste than spontaneous bad taste.
Only the defeated come to possess sound ideas about the nature of things.

After solving a problem, humanity imagines that it finds in analogous solutions the key to all problems.
Every authentic solution brings in its wake a train of grotesque solutions.
We can build nothing upon the goodness of man, but we can only build with it.

Until the end of the 18th century, what man added to nature increased its beauty.
Since then, what he adds destroys it.
The root of reactionary thought is not distrust of reason but distrust of the will.
“Modern art” still seems alive because it has not been replaced, not because it has not died.
The world becomes filled with contradictions when we forget that things have ranks.
To criticize a present in the name of a past can be futile, but to have criticized it in the name of a future can turn out to be risible when that future arrives.
A greater capacity for killing is the criterion of “progress” between two peoples or two epochs.
Few ideas do not turn pale before a fixed glare.
When the tyrant is the anonymous law, modern man believes he is free.

“Liberties” are social precincts in which the individual can move without any coercion; “Liberty,” on the other hand, is a metaphysical principle in whose name a sect seeks to impose its ideals of conduct on everyone else.
The theses that the Marxist “refutes” come back to life unscathed behind his back.
Where even the last vestige of feudal ties disappears, the increasing social isolation of the individual and his increasing helplessness fuse him into a totalitarian mass.

Even when it cannot be an act of reason, an option should be an act of the intelligence.
